11.text:
1916. Europe is in the grips of the most destructive
conflict yet known: World War One.

21.text:
Much of the fiercest fighting take place on
the Western Front, where British, French and

27.text:
German armies are locked in a bloody stalemate
along 450 miles of trenches.

34.text:
There have been millions of casualties, but
neither side can break the deadlock.

41.text:
The combination of barbed wire, machineguns and
heavy artillery means troops trying to cross

47.text:
No Man's Land, the open ground between the
trenches, are slaughtered en masse.

54.text: The advantage is always with the defender.

58.text:
But the Allies are committed to more attacks.
They're determined to liberate the parts of

64.text:
France and Belgium that were occupied by Germany
in the first months of the war.

71.text:
The British and French have agreed to launch
a joint offensive in the summer of 1916.

78.text:
But the Germans strike first. In February,
they launch a massive assault on the French

84.text:
fortress-city of Verdun. Its defence requires
all available French reserves.

93.text:
So the summer offensive will be led by the
British, their biggest attack of the war so far -

98.text:
its chief aim now, to relieve pressure
on the French at Verdun.

115.text:
The attack will take place along a 25 mile
front near the River Somme, in July.

123.text:
The new British commander, General Sir Douglas
Haig, would prefer to attack near Ypres,

129.text:
where there are clearer strategic objectives, but
the Somme is where the British and French

134.text:
armies meet, so where a joint offensive must
take place. He would also prefer to wait until

141.text:
his inexperienced divisions have received
more training... but the French need his help now.

152.text:
The Somme has so far been a quiet sector,
allowing the Germans to build up strong defensive positions.

161.text:
Here the Germans have two formidable, defensive
lines... with a third under construction.

169.text:
Each consists of three lines of trenches:
fire; support; and reserve; connected by communication

177.text:
trenches. They bristle with machinegun positions;
and are anchored on fortified villages and

184.text:
strongpoints. In front of the trenches, there
are thick belts of barbed wire.

191.text:
Below, are dugouts, some 10 metres deep, to
shelter German troops from artillery fire.

199.text:
Telephone lines, buried six feet deep, allow
troops at the front to communicate with artillery

208.text:
The German troops that hold the line are well-trained,
and most are combat veterans.

224.text:
The offensive will be led by the British Fourth
Army, commanded by Lieutenant General Sir

229.text:
Henry Rawlinson. With Haig, he draws up the
plan of attack.

236.text:
To overcome the Germans' formidable defences,
the British will carry out a massive, week-long

242.text:
artillery bombardment with fourteen hundred
guns. This is expected to destroy German barbed

249.text: wire, flatten trenches, and kill their occupants.

255.text:
19 mines are also dug under key German strongpoints,
and filled with explosive, ready to detonate

269.text:
To the north, British Third Army will make
a diversionary attack at Gommecourt.

276.text:
The 16 British and French infantry divisions
are then expected to take their objectives

285.text:
The attack will begin at 7.30am, in broad
daylight, so the artillery can observe its

294.text:
British morale is high, and the men are confident
of victory. Many of the units taking part

300.text:
are Pals Battalions, the eager recruits of
1914, now about to face combat for the first

310.text:
But on the eve of the assault, there are worrying
reports that the British bombardment has been

318.text:
1.6 million shells are fired, but due to inexperienced
gun crews, a shortage of heavy guns, and faulty

327.text:
shells, much of the German barbed wire remains
intact.

333.text:
German defenders, too, are largely unscathed
in their deep dugouts.

339.text:
And from captured prisoners, and listening
in on uncoded telephone calls, the Germans

345.text:
know exactly when and where the British are
coming.

357.text:
The Allied artillery bombardment reaches its
peak at 7am.

363.text:
At 7.20, the British detonate an enormous
mine under a German strongpoint, the Hawthorn

369.text:
Redoubt, and British troops rush forward to
occupy the crater.

376.text:
At 7.28, further mines are detonated under
German strongpoints along the front.

383.text:
At 7.30, the Allied bombardment moves on to
the German second line, as British and French

390.text:
infantry begin their advance across No Man's
Land. German troops, meanwhile, race up from

398.text: their dugouts to set up machineguns.

403.text:
It's an enduring myth that all the British
infantry climb out of their trenches, and

408.text:
walk steadily towards the German line. A few
units do, but most send men out into No Man's

416.text:
Land before the bombardment lifts, so the
final dash toward the enemy line is as short

424.text:
In the northern sector, whichever tactics
are used, the British are easy targets for

430.text:
German machine-gunners, especially where they
bunch up to get through the few gaps in the

438.text:
The British infantry advance bravely, but
are mown down in their hundreds.

447.text:
Some units do break into the German line – near
Thiepval, the 36th Ulster Division captures

453.text:
the Schwaben Redoubt, but without support
on either flank, it's isolated, and the survivors

461.text:
are forced to retreat that night. On their
right, the 32nd Division takes the Leipzig

468.text:
Redoubt. While near La Boiselle, the 34th
Division captures the Lochnagar mine-crater.

477.text:
But these are just small toeholds in the German
line, far short of their objectives.

494.text:
In World War One, one of the greatest challenges
faced by commanders is getting accurate information

500.text:
about the course of the battle. Reliable field
radios haven't been invented yet. Telephone

507.text:
lines are regularly cut by shellfire. So officers
must turn to messengers; flag-signals; light-signals;

518.text:
even homing pigeons - none of which is completely
reliable.

525.text:
To get around this problem, during an attack,
supporting artillery works to a fixed timetable,

532.text:
moving their fire onto the next line of enemy
defences at a set time.

537.text:
So when the infantry start their attack, gunners
adjust their fire onto the second line of

544.text:
But if the infantry get held up, the supporting
fire keeps moving on according to the timetable:

551.text:
the infantry get left behind, and are at the
mercy of enemy machineguns.

558.text:
Aerial observation, by balloons and aircraft,
can provide valuable information, but rely

564.text: on good weather, and control of the skies.

570.text:
This is why on 1st July, it takes British
commanders hours, even days, to find out which

576.text:
attacks have been successful, and which have
failed. This makes it extremely difficult

582.text:
for them to react to the situation with any
speed.

592.text:
Further south, there is much greater success.
Despite heavy losses, the 21st and 7th Divisions

600.text:
take Mametz, and cut-off the heavily-defended
village of Fricourt, which the Germans abandon

607.text:
On their right, the 18th and 30th Divisions
take their objectives, including the village

613.text: of Montauban, which is secure by 11am.

617.text:
Alongside them, the veteran French Twentieth
Corps also takes its first day objectives,

623.text:
as well as two-and-a-half thousand German
prisoners.

627.text:
The Germans didn't expect the offensive to
extend so far south, and are less well-prepared.

634.text:
And crucially, the Allied bombardment is boosted
by French heavy guns, which are much more

639.text:
effective at destroying barbed wire and German
strongpoints.

643.text:
At 09.30am, French colonial troops lead the
attack south of the Somme river. The French

652.text:
seize all their objectives, and take 3,000
more prisoners.

660.text:
Despite success in the south, the first day
of the Battle of the Somme is a costly failure

666.text:
for the British.
Germans losses for the day are estimated at

673.text:
12,000 men; the French lose 7,000. But the
British suffer a staggering 57,000 casualties

682.text:
- one third of them killed.
1st July 1916 becomes the bloodiest day in

692.text: the history of the British Army.

695.text:
And it's just the first day in a battle that
rages for another four months, finally ending

702.text:
in November, amid freezing rain and mud.
By then the Allies have advanced 10 miles,

710.text:
at a cost of 430,000 British casualties; 200,000
French casualties; and 450,000 German.

724.text:
It makes the Battle of the Somme one of the
bloodiest in history.

734.text:
In British popular memory, the Somme is remembered
as an unmitigated disaster, and tragedy: evidence

741.text:
of the incompetence of British generals, and
the pointless sacrifice of the gallant soldiers

747.text:
under their command.
But to those who fought it, and those at home,

753.text:
the Battle of the Somme was seen as a success:
Casualties were enormous, and hard to bear;

761.text:
but across Europe, every warring nation was
suffering terrible losses, as all commanders

767.text: struggled to find an answer to trench warfare.

771.text:
And at the Somme, the British had not only
helped save their French ally, who went on

776.text:
to defeat the Germans at Verdun, but learned
vital lessons about how to fight on the Western

785.text:
Most of all, the Battle of the Somme had been
a costly, but necessary, wearing down of the

791.text:
German army – an immensely painful, but
vital step on the long road to victory.
